course_title: Topics in History and Text: Napoleon's Europe
seats: Seats: Maximum Enrollment: 20 / Seats Avail: 4Waitlist Total: 0
class_notes:
Through analysis of a range of texts, images, and historical debates, this discussion-driven seminar will examine Europe's political and cultural transformations during the ascendancy of Napoleon Bonaparte (1796-1815).  We will explore the nature of Napoleonic rule itself, in France and beyond, as well as such other central themes as the rise of nationalism and romanticism in politics and culture, the experience of soldiers and civilians in an age of intensified warfare, problems of collaboration and resistance in occupied lands, and questions of the revolutionary and modernizing legacies of Napoleon: man and myth.    
Assignments will include active discussion and participation, a short essay (4-5 pages), a book review and presentation (5-6 pages), and two short reading analyses (1-2 pages each).
course_description: The course demonstrates how literary, artistic, and/or cinematic texts, when understood in relation to the context of their production, can be used to study selected historical themes.
